channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Spy Scandal Fells Luxembourg’s Prime Minister
item.description: The actions of Luxembourg's secret service have sent shock waves through the political establishment of a nation best known for its stolid calm.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Dozens of Inmates, Including Terrorists, Flee Indonesian Prison
item.description: The prisoners escaped during deadly rioting over a power failure and water shortage that disrupted fast-breaking for Ramadan.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Police officers stood guard Thursday at the Tanjung Gusta Penitentiary in Indonesia, which rioting prisoners had set ablaze.

item.title: Purported E-Mail From Snowden Asks for Meeting With Rights Groups
item.description: Moscow airport officials say the fugitive American intelligence contractor will meet with human rights representatives.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: India Ink: In Kerala, Rehabilitated Killer Nurtures Mentally Challenged
item.description: Albin Mathew, 62, founded Santhi Bhavan Sarvodaya, a shelter for the mentally challenged after serving a jail term for murder.
item.dc:creator: By SHEVLIN SEBASTIAN
item.media:description: Albin Mathew, a reformed murderer and founder of Santhi Bhavan Sarvodaya, a shelter for the mentally challenged in Alappuzha, Kerala.

item.title: National Briefing | Education: Foreign Students Fill Science Ranks at Universities in United States
item.description: International students make up 70 percent of the full-time electrical engineering graduate students, according to a new report by the National Foundation for American Policy.
item.dc:creator: By TAMAR LEWIN

item.title: Ciudad Juárez Weighs a Neglected Notion: Hope
item.description: With a steep decline in violence and a new mayor taking office, there is a guarded sense of a new beginning in a region plagued by crime.
item.dc:creator: By JULIÁN AGUILAR
item.media:credit: Vanessa Monsisvais for The Texas Tribune
item.media:description: Mariachi band members had their shoes shined in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, on Tuesday. There has been a steep decline in violence in the city.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Prisoners Escape in Indonesia
item.description: About 150 prisoners escaped Thursday after they forced their way out from Tanjung Gusta Prison in Medan, the capital of North Sumatra Province.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Pope Overhauls Vatican Laws
item.description: The legislation criminalized leaks of Vatican information and specifically listing sexual violence, prostitution and possession of child pornography as crimes against children.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Abortion Bill Is Passed in Ireland
item.description: After a grueling debate, lawmakers voted to legalize the practice in exceptional cases where doctors deem the woman’s life to be at risk from her pregnancy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Dozens Killed Across Iraq
item.description: Bombers and gunmen attacked policemen and a wake in Iraq among other targets, killing at least 40 people across the country on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Floods Leave Dozens Dead in China
item.description: Flooding in the western province of Sichuan was the worst in 50 years for some areas, with more than 220,000 people forced to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Is Pressing Latin Americans to Reject Snowden
item.description: The United States is conducting a diplomatic full-court press to try to block Edward J. Snowden from finding refuge in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in Caracas depicts the hand of the Venezuelan government choking Uncle Sam. The rat has “traitor” in Spanish on it.

item.title: Judge Halts Groin Searches at Guantánamo, Calling Them Abhorrent to Muslims
item.description: The federal judge, Royce C. Lamberth, portrayed the procedure as unnecessary and intended to “actively discourage” meetings between detainees and their lawyers.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: London Journal: With Royal Baby Due in Britain, Street Is a Waiting Zone
item.description: No due date has ever been made public for the birth of Prince William and Kate Middleton’s first child, but that hasn’t stopped crowds from forming outside St. Mary’s hospital.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Outside St. Mary’s Hospital, Jessica Bridge kept track of odds on names for the child to be born third in line for the crown.

item.title: U.S. and China to Discuss Investment Treaty, but Cybersecurity Is a Concern
item.description: The United States and China will start negotiating a sweeping bilateral investment treaty, which could open vast sectors of their economies to investments from the other side.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY

item.title: Brazil’s Workers Take to Streets in One-Day Strike
item.description: The “National Day of Struggle,” organized by labor unions and focusing on issues like wages and benefits, disrupted ports and blocked some highways essential to commerce.
item.dc:creator: By LARRY ROHTER
item.media:description: Demonstrators in São Paulo, Brazil, participating Thursday in a strike organized by labor unions.

item.title: Egypt Calls for New Look at Morsi Prison Escape in 2011
item.description: Egypt’s rulers gave new credence to a court case against Mohamed Morsi and members of the Muslim Brotherhood, marking another blow to the group by the military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Relatives of Christians killed near Luxor, where Muslim mobs invaded Christian homes and set them alight while besieging other Christians in their homes.

item.title: Siege by Taliban Strains Pakistani Girls’ Schools
item.description: Since a vicious, high-profile attack on several Pakistani schoolgirls in October, the Taliban’s violent campaign against girls’ education in northwestern Pakistan has continued unabated.
item.dc:creator: By TAHA SIDDIQUI and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Girls attending class in Nowshera. The Taliban see schools as symbols of Western decadence.

item.title: Merkel Appears to Weather Anger Among German Voters Over N.S.A. Spying
item.description: The revelations about N.S.A. surveillance has done little to dent Angela Merkel’s comfortable lead ahead of September elections.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Opposition attempts to paint Chancellor Angela Merkel as untruthful have done little to dent her popularity before elections.

item.title: The Lede: Israeli Army Clears Soldiers Who Detained Child for Throwing Rock at Settler’s Car
item.description: Seven Israeli soldiers who detained a 5-year-old Palestinian boy for rock-throwing this week in the West Bank city of Hebron have been cleared of any wrongdoing by their superiors, after a review of video of the incident.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Genocide Charge Reinstated Against Wartime Leader of the Bosnian Serbs
item.description: Radovan Karadzic will once again be facing two genocide charges for much of the brutal campaign across Bosnia during the 1992-1995 war.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: Radovan Karadzic appeared before a war crimes tribunal on Thursday in The Hague to learn the outcome of an appeal.

item.title: Buddhists Get Prison Terms in Myanmar
item.description: The sentences meted out to more than 20 Buddhists for murder and other crimes after deadly clashes with Muslims in March still left a sense of unequal justice in the Buddhist-majority country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italian Party of Berlusconi Stops Activity in Parliament
item.description: Amid protests from the opposition Five Star Movement, almost all activity stopped in both houses of Parliament for a day.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Powder Room in Parliament? Israelis Scoff
item.description: Outrage erupted on social media after a female politician suggested that a room be set aside so that the record number of women in Parliament could freshen up.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Portugal’s President Calls for Early Elections
item.description: President Aníbal Cavaco Silva called for a new coalition government rather than maintaining the current administration, which has been strained by austerity policies.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
